com.birbit.android.jobqueue

Annotation Type CancelReason


  • @Retention(value=SOURCE)
public @interface CancelReason
    A list of possible reasons why a Job was cancelled. A reason will be passed to Job.onCancel(int, Throwable).

    • Field Detail

      • SINGLE_INSTANCE_ID_QUEUED

        public static final int SINGLE_INSTANCE_ID_QUEUED
        Used when a job was added while another job with the same single instance ID was already queued and not running. This job got cancelled immediately after being added and will not run.

      • REACHED_RETRY_LIMIT

        public static final int REACHED_RETRY_LIMIT
        Used when job throws an exception in Job.onRun() and will be cancelled because it has reached its retry limit.
        See Also:
        Job.getRetryLimit()

      • CANCELLED_WHILE_RUNNING

        public static final int CANCELLED_WHILE_RUNNING
        Used when job throws an exception in Job.onRun() and will be cancelled because it was cancelled via JobManager.cancelJobs(TagConstraint, String...) while it was running.
        See Also:
        JobManager.cancelJobs(TagConstraint, String...), JobManager.cancelJobsInBackground(CancelResult.AsyncCancelCallback, TagConstraint, String...)

      • SINGLE_INSTANCE_WHILE_RUNNING

        public static final int SINGLE_INSTANCE_WHILE_RUNNING
        Used when job throws an exception in Job.onRun() and will be cancelled because another job with the same single instance id was queued while it was running.
        See Also:
        Job.getSingleInstanceId()

      • CANCELLED_VIA_SHOULD_RE_RUN

        public static final int CANCELLED_VIA_SHOULD_RE_RUN
        Used when job throws an exception in Job.onRun() and will be cancelled because it decided not to run again via Job.shouldReRunOnThrowable(Throwable, int, int).

      • REACHED_DEADLINE

        public static final int REACHED_DEADLINE
        Used when a Job is cancelled for hitting its deadline.

        This means the job's params were constructed using Params.overrideDeadlineToCancelInMs(long).
